title: Actress and cancer survivor presents ‘Jonna’s Body’
text:
Actress and cancer survivor presents ‘Jonna’s Body’ Paul Hyde , phyde@greenvillenews.com 6:30 p.m. EDT October 22, 2015 Actress and cancer survivor Jonna Tamases will present a free performance of her play “Jonna’s Body, Please Hold” today (Friday), 11:30 a.m. at Centre Stage. The event also features a panel discussion and light lunch. (Photo: Mad Lively) 17 CONNECT 5 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Jonna Tamases, an actress and three-time cancer survivor, will present a free performance of her play “Jonna’s Body, Please Hold,” today at 11:30 a.m. at Centre Stage. 
The one-woman show traces Tamases’ own struggles against cancer and her eventual triumph. 
“She deals with an awful, sensitive subject in a positive way and with such poignant humor,” said Amy Hammer, president of the Greenville Jewish Federation, a co-sponsor of the event. 
“As a cancer survivor for over 10 years, she’s a real inspiration,” Hammer said. 
The hour-long play will be followed by a panel discussion with Greenville health care professionals. A light lunch also will be served. 
Admission is free, although registration is required by calling 1-877-447-4636. 
In her dark comedy, the Los Angeles-based Tamases plays a sassy operator taking calls from an array of quirky body parts. 
The play was nominated for two Los Angeles Theatre Ovation Awards, including for Best World Premiere Play and Best Lead Actress. 
The panel discussion will include Tamases and three Greenville Health System professionals: 
•Brian McKinley, M.D., surgical oncologist with Greenville Health System’s Breast Health Center. 
•Donald W. Wiper III, M.D., chairman of GHS Department of OB/GYN and a gynecologic oncologist. 
•Gina Franco, manager of GHS Cancer Institute’s Center for Integrative Oncology & Survivorship and herself a cancer survivor. 
The panel will explore strategies for cancer prevention and provide information on new treatments, integrated therapies and research trials. Panelists also will talk about survivorship and unique concerns and challenges faced by survivors. 
Dr. McKinley will address the newly released mammogram guidelines. The American Cancer Society recently recommending that women at average risk of breast cancer get annual mammograms starting at age 45 rather than at age 40, and that women 55 and older scale back screening to every other year. 
The Greenville Health System is also a co-sponsor of the event. 
The Greenville Jewish Federation was particularly interested in sponsoring the event, Hammer said, because eastern European Jewish women have a 40 percent higher rate of breast cancer and 85 percent higher rate of ovarian cancer due to the BRCA gene mutation. 
For the latest in local arts news and reviews, follow Paul Hyde on Facebook and Twitter: @PaulHyde. 
YOU CAN GO 
What: “Jonna’s Body, Please Hold: A Cancerous Dark Comedy,” followed by a panel discussion; light lunch will be served
